content:
**"Permanent Total Disablement"** means a disability caused by an Accident as long as the disability lasts for twelve (12) consecutive months from the date of the Accident, prevents Your Maid from engaging in any kind of occupation or employment for remuneration or profit and at the expiry of that period our appointed Registered Medical Practitioner confirms that the disability is not going to improve after twelve (12) months. We will pay the principal sum insured less any other amount paid or payable under the policy as the result of the same Accident.

**"Personal Belongings"** means articles of personal use designed specifically to be worn or carried by a person e.g clothing, jewellery, watches and camera equipment etc. excluding money, mobile phones, pagers, personal computers and items which are used in connection with any business profession or employment, as well as items insured under a separate policy whether taken with Us or with another insurance company.
questions: How is Permanent Total Disablement defined in terms of duration, medical confirmation, and impact on the Maid's ability to work, and how does the policy handle payments if other amounts have already been paid for the same Accident?
What types of articles qualify as Personal Belongings under the policy, and which specific items are explicitly excluded from this definition?
In the event of a Permanent Total Disablement claim, what role does the appointed Registered Medical Practitioner play in confirming the permanency of the disability after twelve months?
How does the policy treat claims for Personal Belongings that are also covered under a separate insurance policy, and what implications does this have for coverage?
If a Maid suffers an Accident resulting in disability lasting less than twelve consecutive months, how does this affect eligibility for Permanent Total Disablement benefits?
Are items such as mobile phones and personal computers covered under the Personal Belongings section, and what rationale does the policy provide for their exclusion?
When calculating the payout for Permanent Total Disablement, how does the policy account for any prior payments made under the same Accident, and what is the resulting principal sum insured?
Can Personal Belongings include items used for business or professional purposes, and how does the policy address such items in relation to coverage?
What conditions must be met regarding the Maid's ability to engage in any occupation or employment for remuneration or profit to qualify for Permanent Total Disablement benefits?
How does the policy define the starting point for the twelve-month period used to assess Permanent Total Disablement, and what documentation is required to support this timeline?
If a Maid's disability improves after twelve months, how does this affect the confirmation of Permanent Total Disablement and subsequent claim payments?
Are watches and camera equipment considered Personal Belongings, and how does the policy distinguish these from excluded items like money or pagers?
In cases where an Accident leads to Permanent Total Disablement, how does the policy ensure that the disability is not temporary before making a payout?
What exclusions apply to Personal Belongings that are related to employment or business use, and how might this impact claims for items carried during work?
How does the policy handle situations where an Accident causes a disability that prevents the Maid from any form of paid employment but does not last the full twelve months?
What is the significance of the policy specifying that Personal Belongings must be designed specifically to be worn or carried by a person, and how does this affect coverage of other personal items?
If a Maid has multiple disabilities from the same Accident, how does the policy determine the amount payable under Permanent Total Disablement considering previous claims?
Are items like pagers and mobile phones excluded from Personal Belongings coverage even if they are used personally and not for business, and what is the policy's stance on this?
How does the policy differentiate between Personal Belongings and items insured under another policy, and what documentation might be required to prove such coverage?
What is the process and criteria for the appointed Registered Medical Practitioner to confirm that a disability is permanent and will not improve after twelve months?
